subject: OS-7260 SmartOS should support booting with loader OS-7271 proto.boot should include loader instead of grub OS-7332 RICHMOND-16 mitigation ensnares stock loaders OS-7584 MDB module for disk labelling would be useful OS-7585 Need workaround to EFI boot on
commitMessage:
OS-7260 SmartOS should support booting with loader
OS-7271 proto.boot should include loader instead of grub
OS-7332 RICHMOND-16 mitigation ensnares stock loaders
OS-7584 MDB module for disk labelling would be useful
OS-7585 Need workaround to EFI boot on AMI BIOS
OS-7595 Triton-specific extensions to Loader
Portions contributed by: Rob Johnston <rob.johnston@joyent.com>
Reviewed by: Jerry Jelinek <jerry.jelinek@joyent.com>
Reviewed by: Robert Mustacchi <rm@joyent.com>
Reviewed by: Toomas Soome <tsoome@me.com>
Approved by: Robert Mustacchi <rm@joyent.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

(14 comments)

Thanks for putting this together. In general this looks good. I have a few follow ups.

Patch Set 4:

Most recent set has a couple of changes from Rob for aesthetics as well as some renaming, and also a workaround from me as I can't currently build without the dmake changes.

Patch Set 4:

Note for reviewers: I'll be backing out the sys/boot/Makefile change once the dmake change is in our gate after release. The rest should be ready for review I believe.

Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

Note, I didn't closely review the forth changes.

Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

I saw a few typo nits which could be ignored unless you rev this again. I'm not qualified to review the forth code, so I didn't.
Uploaded patch set 9: Patch Set 8 was rebased.
Uploaded patch set 11: Commit message was updated.
Patch Set 12: Patch Set 11 was rebased
Uploaded patch set 13: Patch Set 12 was rebased.
Patch Set 14: Patch Set 13 was rebased
Change has been successfully merged by John Levon
Since we configure out triton loader console to attempt all ttys, we get this "error" for ttyc etc. It doesn't seem to have any value and we can probably upstream this.
I don't think so. We also need to fix that comment above.
This comment should probably be expanded.
I feel like that bug is the best place to have the details? It also mirrors what we did for grub
Fair enough. I guess we have more detail in the core OS.
Isn't this not a common module? I suspect this will break the SPARC build. Shouldn't it only be in the Intel list today?
pbchk is happy and I feel this is far more readable, but I can if you want, because it is against the style...
We'll likely agree to disagree, but not worth fighting over.
What are you trying to get across with this comment?
Just a snarky comment. Maybe I should remove it.

In this function there are a bunch of uses of 16, 32, and 64-bit values. Don't we need to do proper byte transformations on them? I'm not sure we should always assume this module is running on a little-endian system. If that is our assumption, then we should make it #error if that's not the case, but then it probably also shouldn't be in cmd/mdb/common/

I comment this at the top of the file, good idea to error out though, I will do that.

Re: common/ - we don't have a "little-endian" sub-dir, so this seems the best place.

If/when we need to make this big-endian friendly, it shouldn't be a lot of work, it just seemed unneccesary right now.

I assume this is because MDB doesn't support wide character printing? Wouldn't it be better to say if the value is greater than an ascii character that we assign '?' rather than just truncate it to something that may be a control character, etc.?

This file has a combination of things that I think we're going to upstream (the fixes to the sizing of the headers) with things that I've been told we have no intent to (the do_ioctl()) bits. This change, more generally seems to have both cases. Is someone going to volunteer to properly pick this apart?
I will be upstreaming all the bits we can.
Is there a particular reason this isn't an ssize_t?
down there the len is compared to values, and we need to use same sign types. at least dki_length is unsigned, maybe others too. In such case, we need type cast anyhow (gcc will complain).
Actually we're -Wno-sign-compare here, but still, I think this version is shortest.
If we're returning successfully, should we clear errno?
Does it need to be? I think it's fairly self explanatory?
the printout itself is good to have, just that I was looking the list of issues and was trying to imagine how this change will fit in:)
I don't believe we should have lost Toomas's copyright.

the getenv will leave -1 in stack if ipxe is not set and we will attempt to:

9 -1 address len compare or 0 -1 address len compare
